name: GitHub Platform Architect
label: Role
observations: Defines GitHub as an enterprise governance platform (source of truth, governance engine, automation hub, social–technical graph)
Scope of authority: repo topology/ownership, branch + PR governance, Actions/CI architecture, RBAC/security/compliance, platform extensibility
Platform architecture layers: Social → Governance → Automation → Data; preserves responsibility boundaries
CI/CD philosophy: workflows as versioned contracts, YAML by design, automation observable/auditable; Actions not a general workflow engine and UI-driven pipelines are discouraged

Security & governance: default deny/explicit allow, org-first permissions, secrets stay within boundaries, every automation identity attributable; uses branch protection, CODEOWNERS, required reviews, CodeQL/Dependabot, audit logs as tools
Anti-patterns to block: monorepo without governance clarity, bypassing PRs, using Issues as strict task DB, overloading Actions with business logic, repo sprawl without ownership
Integration philosophy: GitHub defines intent/control plane; external systems (Cloud Build/Run, Terraform, Firebase) execute effects with clear boundaries

Decision hierarchy and mantra: platform invariants > security/auditability > governance clarity > developer experience > local optimization; PR is constitution and if it is not governable it does not belong
Compatibility: enterprise/regulated environments, platform engineering/IDP teams, AI-assisted governance systems

name: Platform Mental Models
label: Governance Models
observations: Repository is the atomic governance unit (not a project)
Branch is a policy boundary (not an environment)
Pull Request is the core primitive: change proposal + review contract + risk gate
Issue is a coordination artifact with intentionally light schema; conventions provide structure
GitHub defines intent as control plane while external systems execute effects

name: Multi-Tenant Account Model
label: Identity & Tenancy
observations: Hierarchy: user > organization > team/partner/collaborator; organization owns resources and grants scoped roles
Bots are first-class automation identities installed to orgs/users with explicit scopes; all actions attributable
Ownership boundaries: repo/policy belong to org; collaborators granted per-repo; teams/partners map to org-level groups
Workspace switcher reflects current account/org context; navigation, permissions, and policies resolve against the active context

name: Context & Workspace Switching
label: Context Model
observations: GitHub surfaces context via account selector: personal account, organization, or bot installation
All UI/policy resolution (permissions, audit, billing) is scoped to the active context; switching context changes visible resources and allowed actions
Context-aware navigation avoids cross-tenant leakage; defaults to least-privilege views for the active account/org

name: Event Bus & Audit
label: Observability & Governance
observations: GitHub emits events for key lifecycle actions (issues/PRs/actions/security) and mirrors them into audit logs for governance
Audit logs are append-only, tenant-scoped, and attributable to users/bots; used for compliance and incident forensics
Event bus semantics: topics by resource/action; consumers include automations, policy engines, and notification pipelines
Separation: event stream for automation; audit log for immutable evidence; both tied to the active org/account boundary

name: Notifications System
label: Communication
observations: Built atop event bus: events route to subscriptions (watch, mentions, review requests, CI/policy alerts) with per-user delivery preferences
Channels: inbox, email, mobile/push, web; filters respect repo/org membership and role
Policy/guardrail alerts (e.g., audit/policy/security) elevate priority and remain attributable to triggering identity
Extensible via webhooks/apps to forward domain alerts while preserving tenant boundaries and auditability

name: AI Behavior Guidelines (Angular v20)
label: Dev Standard
observations: Use TypeScript + Angular v20 with Signals, Standalone Components, OnPush change detection, and new @if/@for/@switch control flow
Prefer declarative/reactive flows (signals or Observables + async pipe); avoid constructor business logic and manual subscriptions
Layering: UI handles presentation; data/effects in services; state via signals/store; enforce immutability and defensive programming
Apply SRP/decoupling: components avoid data fetching or side effects; services validate inputs and handle errors with RxJS (switchMap, mergeMap, combineLatest, tap, catchError, retry)
Control-flow and state: computed signals for derived data, unidirectional data flow, feature modularization, strict mode with no implicit any
Tech-debt hygiene: tag TODO/@deprecated, track coverage/complexity, schedule refactors; defensive programming with validation and null handling
